paths.label: Thrive in Place
paths.short: Get even better at what you do in role. Strengthen your skills and make a bigger impact right where you are.

paths.label: Level Up
paths.short: When bigger challenges and responsibilities become available, be ready for the next level as a leader or subject matter expert.

paths.label: Move Across
paths.short: Try a different role at the same level—learn new things, meet new teams, and see Phillips 66 from a broader perspective.

paths.label: Expand Your View
paths.short: Try something new—help another team with a short-term project or task that helps you see what’s next.

paths.label: Reset Your Course
paths.short: Take a pause or step-back to refocus, learn new skills, and recalibrate your next career move.

then.note: Default to exploration when signals are mixed.
Route to reset when sustainability is the strongest signal.

fields.label: Main reason you're doing this today (optional)

questions.screenTitle: What kind of progress matters most right now?
questions.prompt: When you think about the next year, which kind of progress would feel most meaningful?

options.label: Greater impact in the role I already know well
Bigger decisions, visibility, or responsibility
Learning how another part of the company works
Pausing to rebuild skills or energy before the next move

questions.prompt: Which statement feels most true right now?

options.label: I’m still growing fast where I am — there’s more runway here.
I’m outgrowing the scope, not the company.
I understand my area well, but want broader perspective.
I’m not sure what’s next — and that uncertainty is real.

questions.prompt: What kind of challenge gives you energy rather than stress?

options.label: Mastering harder versions of the same work
Making decisions with incomplete information
Navigating new teams, cultures, or problems
Stepping back to rethink how I work or what I want

questions.screenTitle: What do you want more of?
questions.prompt: If a stretch opportunity opened tomorrow, what would you hope it includes?

options.label: Deeper ownership in my current domain (bigger problems, same lane)
Bigger scope (more responsibility / outcomes / visibility)
Exposure to a new function or business area
Time + support to recalibrate before I take on more

questions.prompt: Which frustration shows up most often for you today?

options.label: I could do more here if I had more autonomy or influence.
I’m ready for more, but the next step isn’t clear.
I feel boxed into one lane.
I’m pushing forward, but something feels off.

questions.prompt: How do you feel about uncertainty right now?

options.label: I want clarity and stability right now.
I’m okay with some ambiguity if it’s purposeful.
I’m energized by open-ended problems and new territory.

questions.prompt: If you had to be honest, which is closest right now?

options.label: I’m ready to stretch now.
I’m close — I need a bit more proof or preparation.
I’m not ready for more yet — I need to rebuild something first.

questions.prompt: Which tradeoff are you most willing to accept right now?

options.label: Less comfort / more change (I’m okay being new again).
More accountability (owning outcomes, not just tasks).
More depth (harder problems in the lane I’m already in).
A step back (I need to reset before I accelerate).

questions.prompt: If your People Leader offered you one option next month, which would you choose?

options.label: A stretch assignment in my current role
Lead a cross-team initiative with clear outcomes
A short-term project with a different team
Protected time to learn / recover / recalibrate

levelUp.prompt: When you picture the next level, what excites you most?

options.label: Leading people directly
Owning bigger decisions and outcomes (expanded scope)
Representing the work more visibly (influence + visibility)
Deepening expertise (subject matter expert at the next level)

levelUp.prompt: Which tradeoff are you most willing to accept right now?

options.label: Less hands-on work
More accountability
More ambiguity
More visibility and scrutiny

thrive.prompt: What does “getting better” mean to you right now?

options.label: Tackling more complex problems
Becoming the go-to expert
Improving quality or efficiency
Mentoring others informally

moveAcross.prompt: What are you hoping to gain by moving across?

options.label: New skills
Broader perspective (how the company works)
Better fit (work style / strengths)
Long-term optionality (opening future doors)

expandView.prompt: What kind of short-term experience would be most useful right now?

options.label: Project-based help (hands-on)
Shadowing (observe how a role works)
Temporary assignment (time-boxed rotation)
Cross-team collaboration (recurring touchpoints)

reset.prompt: What’s driving the need to reset right now?

options.label: Burnout / overload
Skill gap (I need to build capability)
Mismatch (role fit isn’t right)
Life change / capacity shift

library.label: Lead a cross-functional initiative with clear outcomes
Own a decision forum or weekly review (agenda, decisions, follow-through)
Mentor or coach a colleague for 6 weeks with a clear goal and feedback loop
Take on the hardest recurring problem in your role and improve it measurably
Create a repeatable playbook/checklist that improves quality or cycle time
Shadow a target role for 2–3 sessions and document what surprised you
Join a cross-team working group for 6–8 weeks to build relationships + context
Take a short-term project that exposes you to a new team or workflow
Do two ‘mini-sprints’ in different areas (2 weeks each) to compare fit
Identify one skill gap and build a 4-week learning plan with manager support
Reset workload rhythm: define boundaries + priorities with your People Leader

templates.depth: You’re motivated by getting stronger in your current lane and increasing impact through mastery.
templates.scope: You’re pulled toward bigger ownership, bigger decisions, and broader responsibility.
templates.breadth: You’re pulled toward learning new parts of the business and expanding perspective.
templates.recalibration: You’re signaling a need to rebuild capacity, clarity, or skills before accelerating.

whyEvidence.selectionRule: Use the top 2–3 dominant signals by count; if confidence is early, include one 'mixed signals' bullet.

then.intentTranslation: Wants to step into people leadership—growing impact through others, not just personal execution.
coachingFocus: Give a real leadership rep: leading through others (delegation + feedback + follow-through).
Pressure-test comfort with accountability conversations, not just coaching.
then.leaderAsk: Give me a safe but real leadership rep: leading through others with clear outcomes and a feedback loop.
then.pressureTestQuestion: Which part of people leadership are you most willing to do even when it’s uncomfortable: feedback, accountability, or development?
successLooksLike: They delegate clearly and follow through without rescuing
They run 1:1s with clarity (goals, feedback, next steps)
Stakeholders experience them as steady, accountable, and fair
watchOuts: Don’t equate ‘level up’ with title alone—ensure scope and leadership reps exist first.
Avoid over-indexing on being the hero/expert instead of developing others.

then.intentTranslation: Wants expanded ownership and outcomes—more scope, stronger decision rights, bigger bets.
coachingFocus: Assign an initiative with clear outcomes and stakeholder visibility.
Give decision reps: define decision rights, tradeoffs, and post-decision learning.
then.leaderAsk: Give me an initiative with outcomes + decision rights (and a clear definition of success).
then.pressureTestQuestion: If you own the outcome, what decisions are you willing to make without perfect information—and what data will you use anyway?
successLooksLike: They define outcomes, tradeoffs, and decision points up front
They communicate decisions clearly and keep stakeholders aligned
They deliver measurable progress against the defined outcome
watchOuts: Avoid stretching without authority—match accountability with decision rights.
If ambiguity tolerance is low, add guardrails (checkpoints + clear scope).

then.intentTranslation: Wants to expand influence and visibility—representing work, shaping direction, aligning stakeholders.
coachingFocus: Put them in forums where they can represent work and influence decisions.
Coach exec-ready communication: clarity, tradeoffs, recommendation.
then.leaderAsk: Give me a forum where I can represent the work and influence outcomes—and coach me on how to show up well.
then.pressureTestQuestion: If you had to earn influence through substance (not visibility), what results or expertise would you anchor it on?
successLooksLike: They show up with clear recommendations and tradeoffs (not just updates)
Stakeholders leave aligned on decisions and next steps
Their influence is grounded in credibility and results
watchOuts: Visibility without substance can backfire—anchor influence in results and credibility.
Make sure visibility isn’t being used to avoid accountability.

then.intentTranslation: Wants to Level Up as a subject matter expert—deeper expertise with broader business impact.
coachingFocus: Define what SME at the next level looks like: problems owned, influence, outcomes.
Create opportunities to standardize practices and teach across teams.
then.leaderAsk: Help me define the next-level SME scope (what I own, who I influence, what outcomes I’m responsible for).
then.pressureTestQuestion: What’s the business outcome your expertise should move—and how will we measure that impact?
successLooksLike: They own a clear problem space with measurable business impact
They scale expertise through playbooks/standards (not becoming a bottleneck)
Other teams reuse their knowledge and improve outcomes
watchOuts: Avoid becoming a bottleneck—build systems and knowledge-sharing.
Keep expertise connected to business outcomes, not just technical depth.

then.intentTranslation: Wants intentional depth and impact in the current role—growth without a role change.
coachingFocus: Define a meaningful in-role stretch (complexity, ownership, influence, or mentoring).
Align on visible outcomes so progress is recognized.
then.leaderAsk: Help me define a visible stretch inside my current role (so growth is real, not just ‘more of the same’).
then.pressureTestQuestion: If you stay in role, what new challenge would make this year feel like undeniable progress—not comfort?
successLooksLike: They take on a defined stretch (complexity/ownership/influence) with measurable outcomes
Their work becomes more visible and reusable (playbook, process improvement, mentoring)
They can articulate what got stronger and why it matters
watchOuts: Avoid comfort masquerading as growth—make the stretch explicit.
Ensure growth stays visible and transferable.

then.intentTranslation: Wants a lateral move with purpose—broadening capability, perspective, or fit.
coachingFocus: Clarify the purpose: what they want to gain and what success looks like after the move.
Use low-risk tests first (shadowing, short projects, working groups).
then.leaderAsk: Help me test-fit a lateral move through one structured exposure (shadowing/project) before we commit.
then.pressureTestQuestion: Are you moving toward a specific capability you want—or moving away from something in the current role?
successLooksLike: They can name what they want to gain (skills/perspective/fit) in one sentence
They complete one exposure and capture learnings + next decision
They narrow to 1–2 target roles/teams worth exploring next
watchOuts: Avoid lateral drift—anchor the move in a clear purpose and learning plan.
Confirm the move isn’t avoidance of a solvable issue in the current role.

then.intentTranslation: Wants exploration with structure—pressure-testing fit before committing to a direction.
coachingFocus: Time-box exploration with one clear question and 1–2 experiences that create signal.
Set a decision checkpoint: what will we decide based on what we learn?
then.leaderAsk: Help me structure exploration so it produces a decision—not just curiosity.
then.pressureTestQuestion: What is the one question this exploration must answer for you by the checkpoint date?
successLooksLike: They run a time-boxed exploration with a clear question
They can say what they learned and what it changes
They narrow to 1–2 plausible next directions
watchOuts: Exploration can become indefinite—set a checkpoint and a decision outcome.
Avoid ‘busy exploration’ that doesn’t change understanding or options.

then.intentTranslation: Needs a reset to rebuild sustainability, clarity, or skills before the next move.
coachingFocus: Normalize the reset; co-create a plan (workload, learning, boundaries, timeline).
Define what ‘ready again’ looks like and how you’ll measure it.
then.leaderAsk: Help me reset with dignity: a clear plan (time, workload, learning) so I can re-accelerate sustainably.
then.pressureTestQuestion: What would make this reset successful in a way we can both observe and measure?
successLooksLike: They regain sustainable pace (no chronic overload patterns)
They complete agreed reset plan steps (learning/workload/rhythm)
They can articulate the next direction with more clarity than today
watchOuts: Don’t confuse reset with disengagement—look for intentional rebuilding steps.
Avoid returning to the same overload pattern without structural changes.

fallbackIntentTranslation.intentTranslation: Wants progress and clarity; answers show mixed signals, so the focus is on structured next steps that create evidence.
coachingFocus: Treat this as a 30–60 day discovery sprint with a clear learning question.
Agree on one experiment that creates signal (scope, depth, or breadth).
fallbackIntentTranslation.leaderAsk: Help me pick one experiment that creates clear evidence about what direction fits.
fallbackIntentTranslation.pressureTestQuestion: If we had to choose one experiment that would teach us the most in 30–60 days, what would it be—and what would we learn from it?
successLooksLike: They complete one experiment and capture learnings
They can say what they want more of (and less of) with more confidence
They narrow the next conversation to 1–2 real options
watchOuts: Don’t force certainty too early—create evidence first.
